articles.headline: A Tablet That Doubles as a Desktop, or Vice Versa
articles.snippet: Lenovo’s new Horizon has a 27-inch touch screen and can be used upright or as a tabletop entertainment hub.
articles.abstract: Lenovo’s new Horizon has a 27-inch touch screen and can be used upright or as a tabletop entertainment hub.
articles.lead_paragraph: The big breakthrough was the iPad: a flat, thin, beautiful, nearly buttonless computer, all touch screen. But that was three years ago.

articles.headline: E-Cigarettes Are in Vogue and at a Crossroads
articles.snippet: The devices that mimic tobacco cigarettes are growing in popularity even as regulators in Europe and the United States weigh their risks.
articles.abstract: The devices that mimic tobacco cigarettes are growing in popularity even as regulators in Europe and the United States weigh their risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent day in the shadow of the Arc de Triomphe, a line of 20 people spilled onto the sidewalk of a trendy new boutique, eager to get a taste of its latest gourmet offerings.

articles.headline: Conflicting Goals Complicate an Effort to Forge a Trans-Atlantic Trade Deal
articles.snippet: A pact is considered unlikely, but the desire for economic growth could overcome political problems.
articles.abstract: A pact is considered unlikely, but the desire for economic growth could overcome political problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The leaders of the European Union, mired in recession and battered by increasing opposition from voters, are desperate for political success to promote economic growth. They are pushing for a rapid negotiation of a trade agreement with the United States aimed at expanding commerce and creating jobs.

articles.headline: Gatekeepers of Cable TV Try to Stop Intel
articles.snippet: Intel’s plan to create a virtual cable service is running up against a barricade being guarded by cable and satellite distributors.
articles.abstract: Intel’s plan to create a virtual cable service is running up against a barricade being guarded by cable and satellite distributors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Intel tries something audacious — the creation of a virtual cable service that would sell a bundle of television channels to subscribers over the Internet — it is running up against a multibillion-dollar barricade.

articles.headline: Starved for Arms, Syria Rebels Make Their Own
articles.snippet: A clandestine network of primitive weapons plants stands as a signature of a militarily lopsided war.
articles.abstract: A clandestine network of primitive weapons plants stands as a signature of a militarily lopsided war.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARAQIB, Syria — The workers arrive by darkness, taking their stations at the vise and the lathe. Soon metal filings and sparks fly, and the stack of their creations grows at their feet: makeshift mortar shells to be fired through barrels salvaged from disabled Syrian Army tanks.

articles.headline: Executive Covets Goldman Seat Where a Friend Snugly Sits
articles.snippet: Gary D. Cohn has long been considered the man who will be the next C.E.O. of Goldman Sachs; the problem is the current chief isn’t ready to leave.
articles.abstract: Gary D. Cohn has long been considered the man who will be the next C.E.O. of Goldman Sachs; the problem is the current chief isn’t ready to leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside Goldman Sachs, Gary D. Cohn is the man who is waiting — and waiting — to be king.

articles.headline: Police Agencies Are Assembling Records of DNA
articles.snippet: Local law enforcement agencies have moved into what had been the domain of the F.B.I. and state crime labs, and the trend is expected only to accelerate after a recent Supreme Court decision.
articles.abstract: Local law enforcement agencies have moved into what had been the domain of the F.B.I. and state crime labs, and the trend is expected only to accelerate after a recent Supreme Court decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: Slowly, and largely under the radar, a growing number of local law enforcement agencies across the country have moved into what had previously been the domain of the F.B.I. and state crime labs — amassing their own DNA databases of potential suspects, some collected with the donors’ knowledge, and some without it.

articles.headline: Gannett to Buy Belo TV Stations, Continuing to Diversify Holdings
articles.snippet: The Gannett Company agreed to buy the Belo Corporation for about $1.5 billion in cash, in a deal that almost doubles Gannett’s television operations.
articles.abstract: The Gannett Company agreed to buy the Belo Corporation for about $1.5 billion in cash, in a deal that almost doubles Gannett’s television operations.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Justices, 9-0, Bar Patenting Human Genes
articles.snippet: The ruling will shape the course of research and testing, and it may alter the willingness of businesses to invest in understanding genetic material.
articles.abstract: The ruling will shape the course of research and testing, and it may alter the willingness of businesses to invest in understanding genetic material.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Human genes may not be patented, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Thursday. The decision is likely to reduce the cost of genetic testing for some health risks, and it may discourage investment in some forms of genetic research.
